The next weekend I came back to the same party, telling myself that I’d approach you this time. But you were busy talking to other girls, and I didn’t want to interrupt. It's absolutely possible to be happy with your body the way it is- but if you really want to change, quick-fix diets and eating disorders aren't going to help. Even if they make you lose weight initially, they almost always end with gaining back the weight you've lost. 

It can be frustrating at times, and will take more work, but making healthy changes and a long-term weight goal is a better option that will bring you not only more success in keeping the weight off, but more satisfaction with your body and self-confidence overall. 

Remember- weight is gained over time, so it's only natural that it's going to take time to lose it. Be patient and focus on a realistic goal, and I promise it'll be worth it. Every time you make a healthy choice, you're taking a step in the right direction, and it will make a difference in the long run. With that mindset you can celebrate your accomplishments, and be happy with the changes- no matter how big or small! (e.g. today I celebrated the fact that I chose tea over chocolate after dinner- a small victory, but it's still something that I'm proud of!)

Your body is already beautiful, and you don't have to make yourself sick to "fix" anything, because there's nothing to fix. Anybody who doesn't appreciate you because you don't fit into their idea of a "perfect" body isn't worth your time anyway. I'm sorry if this sounds like a bit of a cookie-cutter answer, but it's the real and honest truth. There are many, many better ways to achieve a body image you prefer, if that's what you want to do, but honestly, there's no need.

#3960: I'm a girl who's been slightly overweight for most of my life. Every single morning I look in the mirror and hate my body. I also feel like bring overweight has always stopped me from being the person I want to be. I've tried dieting and working out intensely and sometimes I manage to lose a good amount of weight, but I usually always gain it back. I can't think of a time in my life where I've ever been happy with my body. My friends tell me that I'm really pretty and I believe them, but it seems like guys prefer a hot body over a pretty face, and I feel so lonely and unwanted. I just recently started making myself throw up after I eat too much. I hope no one ever catches onto my new bulimia habit because I'm too embarrassed to tell anyone, but at the same time I feel like this is the last resort I can go to to lose weight and finally have the life that i want.

YOU need to think things through a little more thoroughly. You do realize that cigarettes are the only product that if used according to directions will kill you. And smoking is the single greatest avoidable/preventable cause of death among humans. More specifically, nicotine is the only drug that has ZERO health benefits. You are literally shortening your life and everyone's around you when you smoke on campus. And just because we complain about smoking does not mean we think you're less of a person. I don't know where you got that idea, but it's absurd. You feel less of a person because you isolated YOURSELF. Don't blame it on the rest of us. We complain because we care about our health. You should be embarrassed and ashamed by your lack of respect for your fellow students who choose stay healthy and your lack of knowledge on exactly what smoking and second hand smoke does. Get your facts straight, educate yourself, and realize it's more serious than you think. In conclusion, no I'm not going to "shut the hell up and get over it."

I apologize for the lecture, but clearly you needed one.

If you think that you have the right to smoke there, fine.  Do what the non-smokers already did years ago...take it to the university and get the rules changed.  Meanwhile, don't make yourselves look like assholes by bitching because other people (the majority of the students on campus) would like the current rules upheld.

Why should I have to go out of my way to take a different route when you are the one breaking the rules? & excuse me but the LIBRARY?! That's only one of the single most important places for a college student so there's no way to avoid the second hand smoking that you cause.

The breezeway and the sitting area in front of the library are two of the most crowded areas on campus! there are always people passing through....most of whom don't smoke. If you still think that smoking somehow entitles you to something or makes you "cooler", you should get some CBT to knock those silly ideas out of your head.
I wouldn't say smoking cigarettes is having a lack of respect of anyone's life. I totally respect your health.

#3948: To anyone who complains about smoking on campus: shut the hell up and get over it. Those who smoke are people too, and the campus should have a designated smoke area to accommodate all students. If you honestly complain about possibly getting a small, non-harming second hand whiff, get over yourself. You're even lucky that most smokers choose to isolate to one main spot, the library tables, instead of all over campus, which then might be an issue to complain about. And if the school really cared THAT much about it being a smoke-free campus, they would have a security guard tell those people to stop or go off-campus. The school realizes there is an unofficial designated spot.  Sorry if you're too dumb to realize that. Think things through a little more thoroughly, and if you're incapable of doing that, at least go the other way and walk through the breezeway under the library to avoid it.

Sincerely, UM smokers.

P.S. Just bought a pack, specifically to smoke in front of the library.

We got that southern hospitality
I'm incredibly polite and from Philadelphia. I think it's more we don't have time for a lot of the "Southern Hospitality" and we're always on the go. It's not that we're rude, we're just more direct

Having spent half my life in the north and half in the south, I might be able to shed some light on the subject...maybe. People from the north are from very tightly knit communities that rely on trust, a trust which is hard to earn and harder to keep. People from the south have a more relaxed mentality of how social interactions  happen and as such generally are slow to grudge and quick to forgive and forget, unlike their northern counterparts. If you look reaaaally deep, and this might just be speculation, you might notice that some practices that were important in the northern history of industry are important in how northern parents raise their children, while other values are "encouraged" in southern families, both respectable, but both delivering children with different tolerances and reactions to society. This is such a deep topic that my explanation is like looking at one grain of sand on a beach and being able to draw the beach just by looking at the grain. But I hope it helps a little bit. :)
Southerners are generally nicer people
Rash generalizations are rude too

So true! Lived in Georgia for most my life. Southern hospitality is the norm and its a hard habit to break but not a bad one! Really the way we are raised is different. It probably has a lot to do with the fact that the north was industrialized earlier. it seems unrelated but think about that for a second. Our mentalities are a bit different and southern life is just...slower in general. Theres more time to be nice :)

#3915: The amount of times I hear people express how much they loathe "fat" people never fails to disgust me. I had a really good friend who was overweight, and he was one of the most down-to-earth people I've ever known. In a matter of six months, he's lost over 40 pounds, and he's never been the same. While I was proud of his accomplishment, I'd be surprised if he still remembers that I exist; he's been so distant and condescending that I can't even recognize him anymore. If I had to choose between having him skinny and rude, or having him fat and genuinely loving, I'd choose the latter. I'd give anything to have my old friend back. So please, before we negatively judge someone's exterior, let's celebrate the goodness within them that may cease to exist once they lose weight and become conceited bastards.

I disagree with the whola "quota" comment but I also hate when people throw out the whole "UM is so diverse".  Yes, we are one of the most diverse compared to other schools but overall the vast majority of universities are not diverse. UM just tops the charts on an overall LOW scale. Some black girls don't plaegde because they don't want to, others pledge but when the sorority is majority white, there may be some bias. It's the same the other way around, how many white girls do you see pledging to black sororities? It sucks because our campus isnactually really segregated but the fault does not only lie on "blacks" or "whites" shoulders. It's both. Plus the black-white racial dichotomay completely ignores the other races who are also underrepresented and "keep to themselves" such as Asians, Hispanics, Caribbean and African students, International kids who only hang out with other internationals (Brits, Aussies, etc). BMI is a terrible measure designed to make generalizations regarding the population as a whole based on a a height-weight ratio of a sedentary adult. I'm obese by BMI, when I came to college I was considered underweight. I wasn't unhealthy at either bodyweight, just smaller at one. I still eat similar foods, mostly meat/veggies, just a lot more. The point is, weight doesn't mean shit unless you view it in context. If you're unhealthy, fix that and stop being unhealthy.
You guys are beautiful. Don't let these fat-shaming/overweight-shaming individuals get you down. Besides, you can be overweight and NOT be fat and STILL be healthy!

I mean, unless it's a legitimate medical problem that can't be taken care of, then good. Maybe it will start giving people the motivation to either seek help (if they can't do it on their own) or push themselves to get off their asses and go forward into a healthier lifestyle, put down the soda and cheeseburger, pick up the water and fruits/veggies, and start working out. I'm a chubby guy, and I'm glad that I've had not only people around me, but also society (even if some of it's a bit shallow in its reasoning), push me to start losing weight and living healthier. And I've lost nearly 15lbs because of it, and I've just started.

I love the amount of people that bitch about smoking(a chemical dependence), but apparently being overweight isn't a health problem anymore. Guess I don't have to worry about diabetes anymore! I'll eat whatever I want! Fuck exercising.

Nick Henderson, the difference between smoking and being overweight is that smoking is always and undeniably detrimental to your health. Someone can be classified as overweight or even have just a little fat on them, but they can still be healthy on a physiological level.  Being overweight and being unhealthy are not always on the same side of the same coin. Jordan Reimers even touches upon this in his comment.

BMI was developed by life insurance companies, NOT doctors. It provides a general estimate of who will live longest, not healthiest. According to my BMI, I am overweight. According to fashion industry, if you're above a size 4, you're plus-sized. But when high school me was worried and asked my doctor, she said I was on the skinny side.

I don't think you understand the concept of overweight. Being overweight literally means that you have an unhealthy weight. Now, if you can somehow weigh 500 lbs of fat and still be healthy, more power to you. It's just stupid to tell people that there's nothing wrong with unhealthy diet and exercise habits. If you're one of the 0.001% of people with a legitimate medical issue, that sucks, but it's still not even an excuse to not at least try to be helpful. Never be satisfied with yourself. You can always be better
You're fat.
Fun fact: according to BMI, Lebron James is considered obese.

Nick, I stand by my previous comment: "Someone can be classified as overweight...but they can still be healthy on a physiological level." This confession was mostly addressing classifications in terms of BMI - this is what I am referring to. If you research, you will find that there is some faultiness to the standard BMI classifier.  Someone who is a bodybuilder can be considered "overweight" in terms of clinical BMI.

I think that everyone who chose to come to MIAMI, came with complete knowledge about what the climate was like here. I also like season's, that's why I picked the place where I constantly live in the best one. If you like a good cold winter so much you should have went to a different school.

That is a load of shit. It is miserably hot and humid down here, and it's barely even dipped below the 70's since 2014 started. Seriously. Miami has like one or two "real" seasons. Summer and slightly cooler summer. We do not have it "good" in terms of weather, compared to other schools. Don't get me wrong, it's nice in short intervals (i.e. vacation spot), but that's it. I'd take anywhere from north Florida up to Tennessee and over to Texas and Colorado, over Miami in terms of weather. You know, somewhere that actually has four real seasons year-round. #rantover
